High-curvature single-atom catalysts for electrocatalysis: A review Caili Chen Writing – original draft Zekai Zhang Writing – review & editing Liangli Dai Writing – review & editing Bolin Li Writing – review & editing Zesheng Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology ⁎ College of Chemistry, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming 525000, China College of Chemistry, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology Maoming 525000 China College of Chemistry, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, 525000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The catalytic performance of a high-curvature single-atom catalyst is highly dependent on its geometry and the type of metal atoms it carries. This review uses a combination of extensive literature research and theoretical analysis to comprehensively analyze several key aspects of high-curvature single-atom catalysts, including dimension, energy, reaction mechanism, radius of curvature, reaction selectivity, size, different metal atoms, and different types of reactions. In this paper, the unique advantages of high-curvature single-atom catalysts are successfully summarized and refined. On the one hand, it has been found that the surface of this catalyst is highly curved, which promotes the adsorption and reaction of atoms. On the other hand, this paper states that choosing the right radius of curvature is essential to optimize the catalytic process. The comprehensive literature analysis in recent years may provide important reference and enlightenment for researchers, promote the further development of the field of catalysis, and develop more advanced high-curvature single-atom catalytic materials. Graphical Abstract In this review paper, the basic definition, structural types, structural advantages, design philosophy, and application progress of high-curvature single-atom catalysts are summarized and analyzed. Keywords Single atom catalysts High curvature Carrier effect Electrocatalysis Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Academician Tao Zhang and his colleagues designed and prepared the first Pt1/FeOx single-atom catalyst (SACs) in 2011, and proposed the concept of “single atom catalysis” in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [1]. The team led by Tao Zhang is dedicated to the development of oxide supported SACs. They have successfully prepared a series of precious metal SACs loaded on different oxides such as iron oxide, titanium oxide, and cerium oxide, covering elements such as platinum (Pt), gold (Au), and rhodium (Rh) [2]. These findings have important guiding significance for the precise synthesis of efficient SACs. Academician Yadong Li also mentioned that SACs have the characteristics of maximizing atomic utilization and isolating active sites, making them a very prosperous branch of catalytic research in recent years [3]. The main objective of SACs research is to establish feasible synthesis strategies for preparing high-performance catalysts, gain a deep understanding of the active site structure and catalytic mechanism, and develop practical catalysts with industrial value. Yadong Li et al. also investigated the covalent metal support interactions present in SACs systems, as well as the traditional strong metal support interaction mechanism[4]. Due to the close atomic size of metal particles on SACs, they possess unique electronic structures, quantum size effects, and maximum atomic utilization [5]. In short, the SACs are a special type of metal supported catalysts, which specifically refer to the presence of metal components on the support in the form of atomic dispersion, and the absence of metal-metal bonds with the same atom. Over the past few decades, SAC has been widely used in CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR), attributed to its optimal atom utilization and well-defined centers of activity. At the same time, carbon-based SACs are key players in electrocatalysis due to their structural versatility, superior stability, and superior electrical conductivity[6]. Moreover, in single atom alloys (SAAs), the reconstruction of the electronic structure between the host metal and the guest metal is essential to drive the hydrogenation reaction [7]. However, in some applications, the performance of SACs s will also be inferior to that of other materials, such as Lili Zhang et al. reported that due to their symmetrical electron distribution, their oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance is still inferior to that of the benchmark iridium and ruthenium-based catalysts, so diatomic catalysts (DACs) A-Fe2S1N5/SNC, where A denotes asymmetry. SASs still contain great development potential, and their future development space is extremely broad [8]. Curvature is a quantity that describes the degree of curvature of an object. The smaller the radius of curvature, the greater the curvature. High-curvature materials are a class of advanced functional materials with highly curved shapes and structures, typically possessing complex multi-level structures, such as onion like carbon structures [9], carbon nanotubes [10], curved carbon nanosheets [11] are often used as catalysts or catalyst carriers due to their unique surface and interface characteristics. Showing excellent electrochemical performance, with the continuous progress of related technologies, we believe that this type of material can bring more innovation and breakthroughs. However, improving the catalytic efficiency of catalysts and reducing catalyst costs are huge challenges in the field of catalysts research. In the field of electrocatalysis, high-curvature SACs stand out from many traditional catalysts due to their unique structural characteristics and catalytic performance, becoming a research hotspot in recent years. Single atom high-curvature catalysts have active sites composed of individual metal atoms on high-curvature carrier materials [12–14]. In the case of high-curvature, single-atoms can maintain performance stability, and these atoms are dispersed on the surface of the carrier in the form of single-atoms and connected to the carrier by bonding with heteroatoms. This structure allows each metal atom to be fully exposed to the reaction environment, thereby improving catalytic efficiency [15]. The metal active sites of the high-curvature SACs are generally uniformly distributed on the curved support, presenting the form of highly localized electric fields, which is conducive to improving the catalyst efficiency, that is, increasing the chemical effective collision. The curvature structure of the support can be changed to make the metal atoms have local high concentration charge distribution, thereby improving the catalytic activity and selectivity of the catalyst. For example, the carbon substrate curvature studied by Chunyu Du's team at Harbin Institute of Technology enhances ORR by regulating the in-situ geometric distortion of CuN2C2 single-atom sites [16]. The study investigates the different dimensions and structural characteristics of this catalyst, analyzes the effects of different shapes, catalyst faces, sizes, and other conditions on electrocatalytic efficiency, atomic adsorption capacity, atomic stability, uniformity of dispersion, and reduction of reaction energy barriers. For example, in a study by Fan Jun and others [17], it was found that there are free moving carriers in the Fermi level, which can significantly enhance the conductivity of the material. The presence of this carrier enhances the potential of the material in efficient electrocatalytic applications. Through the research and analysis of this catalyst from different aspects, we believe that in the field of catalysis in the future, higher curvature, more convenient and efficient binding of atoms, and higher stability, green and environmentally friendly high-curvature SACs can be developed. The bending and narrow shape of high-curvature single-atoms affect the geometric characteristics of catalysts, and they have a significant impact on catalytic performance. In high-curvature SACs, bending usually refers to the degree of curvature of the carrier material. High-curvature means that the surface of the carrier exhibits more curvature and concavity, which can provide more active sites and increase the contact area between the catalyst and reactants. Narrow refers to specific areas or channels on the surface of a catalyst, which are small in size and can limit the diffusion path of reactants or products. This structure helps to improve the selectivity of the catalyst, as it can make it easier for specific types of reactants to come into contact with active sites, while other molecules are restricted from entering. The research by XiwenDu's team on the clamp catalytic mechanism within metal nanopores confirms this idea [18]; There is also a report on the study of carbon with negative bending: hypothetical ring-shaped carbon nanotubes composed of five membered, six membered, and seven membered rings exhibit positive curvature on the outside of the torus and negative curvature on the inside of the torus [19]. These carbon allotropes with negative curvature have interesting properties and potential applications. It has been found from calculations that the flexible polycyclic framework of negative curvature nanographene is related to the stereochemical kinetics that planar polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons do not possess. In addition, some negatively bent graphene nanoparticles have been found to act as organic semiconductors in the solid state. This review mainly focuses on the concept and application of high-curvature SACs; Research on the performance of high-curvature SACs with different sizes, catalyst fabrication methods, dimensions, shapes, and concave convex surfaces, and summarizing their differences and proposing the influence of curvature radius on SACs; The application of SACs in The application of single-atom catalysts in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), N2 reduction reaction (NRR), and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). Finally, the size effect of the carrier was also proposed, and the application of nano islands was introduced, proposing prospects for the future development of SACs. This review combines multiple studies on SACs and contains rich case studies, providing high reference value for the development of SACs. 2 The classification of high-curvature single-atoms and the influence of curvature radius 2.1 Classification of high-curvature single-atom carriers When discussing carriers with high-curvature characteristics, we typically consider zero-dimensional (0-D) quantum dots, one-dimensional (1-D) carbon nanotubes, and three-dimensional (3-D) complex structures. Although two-dimensional materials are traditionally regarded as planar carriers and not possessing high-curvature characteristics, in fact, two-dimensional materials such as graphene can also form three-dimensional morphologies with high curvature after undergoing specific processing. The curvature effect exhibited by carriers of different dimensions often has different enhancement effects on metal SACs [20,21]. Previous studies on the oxygen adsorption, formation, and thermal stability of platinum oxide on Pt nanoparticles supported by Si oxide have found that the size effect affects the strength of O binding, which is beneficial for their ability to form oxides. In addition, a clear size dependent trend was observed, with an increase in oxygen bond strength and a decrease in nanoparticles size [22]. In this review paper, we divide the curvature effect of the carrier into three types: convex curvature (such as nanosphere), concave curvature (such as concave nanocubes and mesoporous carbon) and convex-concave mixed curvatur (curved nanotubes, spiral nanotubes, and curved nanosheets) (see Fig. 1). 2.1.1 Zero dimensional carrier SACs supported on small-sized zero-dimensional carriers can induce the formation of "tip structures", generating intense local electric fields in high-curvature tip regions due to curvature concentration, significantly enhancing the reactivity of the catalyst's active sites and thereby accelerating the catalytic reaction rate. Additionally, the "structural distortion" effect, also known as bond length modulation, occurs on high-curvature carriers, leading to changes in the bond length between the metal single atom and the carrier. This change further adjusts the electronic structure of the metal single atom, influencing its catalytic performance. On the other hand, the "compressive strain" effect, also referred to as the d-band center effect, refers to the shift in the d-band center position of the metal single atom caused by the compressive force exerted by the high-curvature carrier. The position of the d-band center is crucial for the adsorption and desorption processes of the catalyst. By adjusting this position, the adsorption performance of the catalyst can be optimized, thereby enhancing catalytic efficiency and selectivity. Man Yang et al. studied a high-curvature nanosphere [23–26] that is doped into a nanodiamond with a high-curvature surface by isolated Fe single atoms, resulting in a curved Fe1-N4 single-atom site[27] (see Fig. 2).PMS is first activated at the bent Fe1-N4 site and provides electrons to Fe single-atom, while producing 1/2 equivalent of 1O2. More importantly, due to the compressive strain of the bent Fe1-N4 site of the Fe 3dz 2 orbital with higher energy levels, the bent Fe1-N4 site with electron charge acquisition can directly transfer electrons to the O2 molecule, triggering the generation of an additional 1 equivalent of 1O2. By using this serial process, the efficiency of 1O2 production is significant, with selectivity close to 100 %. It has an ultra-high metal catalytic efficiency of 0.77 min−1 for tetracycline oxidation degradation and excellent catalytic performance for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Fullerenes are a unique class of molecules composed of pure carbon atoms, characterized by hollow geometric structures that are spherical, ellipsoidal, columnar, or tubular in shape. These molecules are similar in morphology to graphite, but unlike graphite that is only composed of hexagonal layers, fullerene structures not only contain hexagonal rings, but also pentagonal rings, and occasionally heptagonal rings. As the only known pure carbon molecule with precise structure and solubility in certain solvents, the internal cavity of fullerene can encapsulate various metal atoms or their clusters, forming so-called metal fullerene complexes. Among the various crystal forms of fullerene, C60 nanowires, as one-dimensional nanostructures of C, are of particular interest due to their excellent performance and high surface area, low dimensional potential quantum confinement effects, and potential applications as one-dimensional building units in magnetic and photonic applications[28–30]. Many scientists have conducted a series of studies on this fullerene material. Professor Geng Junfeng's research group reviewed the latest research progress of fullerene (C60) nanowires, including their preparation techniques, analysis and characterization methods, crystal and chemical structures, and delves into the polymerization process of nanowires. Special attention has been paid to the latest developments in the practical application of fullerene (C60) nanowires. Researchers from Columbia University have reported a novel two-dimensional polymer called Graphullerene [31]. This material is composed of C60 molecules connected by covalent bonds to form a hexagonal lattice structure, breaking the traditional boundary between molecules and carbon materials. The research team also successfully constructed charge neutral, pure carbon macroscopic crystal materials, providing new ideas for designing heterostructures and optoelectronic devices. Huang Wenhuan and Lu Xing used fullerene as a bifunctional additive to synthesize fullerene intercalated graphene phase carbon nitride (C60@CN) composite materials and their application in sodium ion batteries [32]. They systematically studied the effects of fullerene addition on the morphology, interlayer spacing, and electrochemical performance of materials. The results showed that the addition of fullerene effectively increased the interlayer spacing and specific surface area by utilizing its spatial size effect, increased the boundary nitrogen defects of the material, and promoted the insertion and diffusion of Na+ions. Meanwhile, due to the high conductivity of fullerene, this high conductivity significantly improves the C60@CN composite material, accelerating the transfer of ions and electrons during the charging and discharging process. Lu Xing and Xie Jia reported on the study of using nitrated fullerene (C60(NO2)6) as an electrolyte additive for sodium metal batteries [33]. They synthesized a highly soluble nitrofullerene through molecular structure design to protect the negative electrode of sodium metal batteries. This additive is not only highly compatible with the electrolyte, but also effectively promotes the uniform deposition/stripping of sodium ions and inhibits the formation of sodium dendrites. This study not only provides a new solution for improving the performance of sodium metal batteries, but also expands the application range of fullerene materials. 2.1.2 One dimensional carrier The unique curvature of one-dimensional carriers (metal nanorods or nanowires) affects the degree of structural distortion of single-atomic sites during catalytic reactions, which in turn affects the electron transfer from active sites to adsorbed species and ultimately affects reaction activity (this distortion can vary from the bond length between metal single-atoms and surrounding atoms). Chunyu Du's team from Harbin Institute of Technology used single-atom Cu dispersed on carbon nanotubes of different diameters as a model to demonstrate the dynamic behavior of CuN2C2 sites during in-situ ORR, revealing the substrate strain tuning geometric distortion of active sites and their correlation with activity[16]. Research has shown that graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have a clear and uniform sp2 hybrid carbon skeleton structure, providing an ideal model substrate for studying the structure function relationship of SACs. Compared with graphene, CNT has more sp3-like C atoms and the strain C-C bonds generated by geometric bending [34–36]. Curved carbon substrates may lead to unique dynamic evolution of active sites, thereby manipulating the catalytic process of SAC [37,38]. Atomic dispersed unsaturated Cu-N3 sites synergistically enhance NRR of ammonia on high-curvature level porous carbon nanotubes [39] (see Fig. 3). Low coordination Cu-N3 SAC was prepared on high-curvature porous nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) using a step-by-step polymerization surface modification electrostatic adsorption carbonization method (Fig. 3). This study inspires a synergistic enhanced catalytic strategy to create an unsaturated coordination environment and regulate the carrier structure. Tianfu Wang and his team have shown that single nickel atoms positioned on the curved surfaces of porous carbon exhibit enhanced catalytic activity. Specifically, the NiN4 sites found on these curved carbon surfaces boast a higher density of states (DOS) and lower energy barriers in comparison to those on flat surfaces, thereby fostering superior catalytic performance. This discovery holds significant potential for CO2RR to produce CO, effectively bridging the material gap between renewable energy production and the existing petrochemical infrastructure. [40]. Jianjun Su et al. conducted electrocatalytic CO2RR using CNTs, achieving a methanol selectivity of over 60 % [41] (see Fig. 4). This study unveils the crucial role of CNTs in inducing Å-level molecular distortions to modulate catalytic activity. The researchers utilized CNTs as carriers with monodispersed cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) as the catalyst. Through spectral data, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, they confirmed the enhancing effect of geometrically distorted CoPc on electrocatalytic performance. In this paper, the authors demonstrate that carbon nanotubes, particularly single-walled CNTs (SWCNTs), serve as ideal carriers for inducing optimal catalytic performance through molecular curvature. An assembled cascade flow cell electrolyzer with single-walled CNTs loaded with monodispersed cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc/SWCNTs) as the catalyst exhibited a methanol partial current density of up to 90 mA cm⁻² and a selectivity exceeding 60 % during the CO2RR process, significantly outperforming catalysts based on multi-walled CNTs. The results of the DFT calculations indicate that, within the assessed voltage range, bent CoPc exhibits a stronger CO adsorption energy compared to planar CoPc. For example, the CO adsorption energies of bent and planar CoPcH4 at −1.0 V vs. RHE are −1.41 eV and 0.25 eV, respectively (Fig. 4a). Therefore, the adsorption capacity of bent CoPcH4 is stronger, which is conducive to the further reduction of CO to methanol. However, flat CoPcH4 is more prone to CO desorption, which is not conducive to the formation of methanol (Fig. 4b). Therefore, for planar CoPc, the formation of CO intermediate products tends to be more inclined towards CO desorption to generate CO products, which are difficult to continue reducing to produce methanol. For curved CoPc, the stronger binding energy between the intermediate product CO and Co center makes it possible to further convert to methanol, which is consistent with the experimental results. Due to the presence of bending induced stress in CoPc, the energy of bent CoPcH4 is higher than that of its planar molecules. However, after the catalyst adsorbs CO, the bent CoPcH4 (CO) exhibits lower energy compared to the planar CoPcH4 (CO) (Fig. 4c), indicating that the stress in the molecule favors the binding of active Co sites to CO. We further investigated the geometric shapes of the important intermediate, CoPcH4 (CO), under the introduction of different numbers of charges, to understand how the CO binding energy varies with voltage (Fig. 4d). Under all introduced charges, the curvature of CoPcH4 (CO) maintains a smaller N-Co-N angle, indicating a more severe out of plane distortion (Fig. 4e). In addition, compared to planar CoPcH4 (CO), bent CoPcH4 (CO) has shorter Co-C bonds and longer C-O bonds. We speculate that the longer C-O bond length makes it easier for the intermediate product CO to undergo further reduction reactions, thereby increasing the selectivity of methanol (Fig. 4f). The theoretical calculation results of the full step DFT from CO2 to methanol at −0.93 V vs. RHE (Fig. 4g) show that the bent CoPc has a more negative Gibbs free energy in all reaction steps. For the important intermediate product CO in this step, the planar CoPc tends to desorb CO to generate CO products, while in the curved CoPc, the binding force between * CO and Co centers is stronger, which is conducive to further generation of * OCH and the final product methanol. In summary, zero-dimensional (e.g., nanodiamonds, fullerenes) and one-dimensional (e.g., carbon nanotubes) and even three-dimensional high-curvature carrier materials have many similarities despite their different dimensions. In terms of structural characteristics, they all have significant high curvature properties, which are achieved by bending, twisting, or constructing specific nanomorphologies such as nanowires, nanospheres, and helical structures, which greatly increase the surface area and number of active sites of the material. These high-curvature supports show great potential in the field of catalysis to effectively anchor metal single atoms to form SACs. By carefully manipulating the metal-support interaction and electronic structure, these SACs can significantly improve their catalytic activity and selectivity. However, there are significant differences in the catalytic mechanisms of different types of vectors. Specifically, the various carriers affect the electronic structure of metal monoatoms in different ways. For example, in nanodiamond, the curved Fe1−N4 site can optimize the catalytic performance through the compressive strain effect. On carbon nanotubes, the Cu-N3 site can achieve synergistic enhancement of the catalytic effect by constructing an unsaturated coordination environment and regulating the carrier structure. These differences make different types of high-curvature supports show unique advantages and applicability in catalytic reactions. In addition, the stability of these high-curvature carriers needs to be paid attention to. Under some harsh application conditions, high-curvature carriers may face challenges such as structural deformation or active site detachment. Therefore, in practical applications, we need to carefully screen the appropriate support dimensions and forms according to the specific catalytic reaction type and application requirements to ensure the stability and catalytic performance of the catalyst. 2.2 Differences in carrier concave and convex surfaces There are significant differences in morphology between concave and convex nanomaterials. As shown in the Fig. 11, concave nanomaterials have a concave surface morphology, and their surface is inward curved with negative curvature. In contrast, convex nanomaterials have a raised surface morphology, with their surface protruding outward and exhibiting positive curvature. The difference between these two morphologies leads to their differences in properties and applications. I believe that concave nanomaterials and convex nanomaterials have a wider contact surface with the material during the reaction, making it easier to combine with the material. Compared to concave nanomaterials, concave nanomaterials have a smaller contact area and slightly poorer catalytic performance due to domain limitation issues. Concave and convex nanomaterials also have different characteristics in catalytic activity. Convex nanomaterials typically exhibit higher catalytic activity, as the convex surface provides more active sites, increasing the contact area between reactants and catalysts. For single-layer catalysts, the thin material results in a larger curvature and contact area with the convex surface of the multi-layer catalyst. This configuration provides more active sites, leading to a more stable reaction and higher efficiency. The convex surface of a multi-layer catalyst is influenced by the interaction forces between its layers. Due to the stacking of multiple layers, the curvature differs from that of a single-layer catalyst, causing the convex surface to approximate a plane and reducing the area of the concave surface. From the perspective of carrier classification, for zero-dimensional carriers, nanospheres are convex. For one-dimensional carriers, catalysts are mostly straight nanowires or nanotubes. The surface of the tube is convex, while the inner surface of the tube is concave. For three-dimensional carriers, catalysts include spiral nanotubes, curved nanosheets, and three-dimensional nanopores. Spiral nanotubes and curved nanotubes have both convex and concave surfaces, respectively, while three-dimensional nanopores have concave surfaces. Du Xiwen's team studied the pincer catalytic mechanism within metal nanopores [18]. They found that the concave surfaces of the nanopores possess unique geometric and electronic structures, which can act like a "pincer" to simultaneously capture CO2 and H2O molecules, thereby reducing the reaction energy barrier. This "pincer" is composed of three atoms: a negatively charged axial atom and two positively charged jaw atoms. When one jaw site adsorbs a water molecule, charge redistribution occurs, making the other jaw atom more suitable for adsorbing CO2 molecules. Under the action of hydrogen bonding, CO2 is rapidly activated and bent. As a result, both the activation barrier of the reactants and the subsequent reaction energy barrier are lowered, favoring the production of carbon monoxide (CO) as the final product. This unique structure with negative curvature reveals the distinct catalytic mechanism of concave surfaces in metal nanopores. This provides new insights for designing novel catalysts by leveraging special geometric structures to enhance catalytic performance. These microstructural differences can significantly induce adjustments and changes in electronic structure, charge state, and local chemical environment, thereby exerting fine control over the electron density distribution of active sites. This regulatory mechanism may reshape the adsorption mode of reactant molecules, altering their adsorption manner and strength, and further influencing the selection of chemical reaction pathways and the stability of intermediate products. Additionally, these microstructural differences profoundly affect the charge transfer efficiency between SACs and reactant molecules, namely the rate and efficiency of charge transfer between the catalyst and the reactants. These intricate effects interact and collectively influence the catalytic activity and selectivity of SACs in a profound and significant manner. In the study by Mengru Liu and colleagues, they focused on the impact of nitrogen coordination types in metal-nitrogen structures on the catalytic performance of nitrogen-doped carbon-based SACs[51] (see Fig. 14 a-b). At zero curvature (i.e., on a flat plane), two distinct molecular structures were observed surrounding the central nitrogen atom: one featuring alternating six- and five-membered rings, and the other consisting solely of six-membered rings. Although this review has delved into the high curvature characteristics of SACs, it is noteworthy that the impact of their microstructure on performance cannot be overlooked, even under the same curvature conditions. This observation suggests that curvature, as a key factor in macrostructure, indeed significantly influences the overall performance of catalysts. However, deeper exploration reveals that at the microscopic level, the molecular structure of catalysts may be a more fundamental and direct factor contributing to performance variations. Specifically, the microstructure of catalysts, such as the molecular structure of carbon rings and the crystalline structure of metal supports, can have important effects on catalytic reaction pathways, the number of active sites, and reaction kinetics. Changes in these microscopic features, even under the same curvature conditions, can lead to significant differences in catalyst performance. Therefore, for SACs, future research should focus more on deeply exploring the specific mechanisms through which their microstructure influences performance under the same curvature conditions. This will also open up new research directions for the precise synthesis and regulation of catalysts, driving the development of catalysis science. 2.4 Curvature radius law and its impact on SACs The authors speculate that the catalytic performance of nanocatalysts changes with the change of radius of curvature, and that high-curvature carrier materials can also optimize their catalytic performance by manipulating the electronic structure and structure-activity relationship of metal single-atom sites. The curvature of the carrier exerts localized stress on RuN2B1, compressing the Ru-N bond and enhancing the electron-donating ability of Ru (Fig. 19a). Conversely, the Ru-B bond is elongated, which weakens the electron-accepting ability of Ru, resulting in the accumulation of positive charge on Ru during this process (Fig. 19b). The differential charge density and projected density of states (PDOS) reveal that some electrons from the Ru-d orbital transfer to the B-p orbital at the bending point, causing the energy level of the d-orbital to shift upward and leading to the disappearance of spin polarization (Fig. 19c). The combined effects of positive charge accumulation and the loss of spin polarization in the Ru-d orbitals contribute to the formation of RuN2B1 with ΔGH* < 0.4 eV, making it more suitable for hydrogen evolution (ΔGH*) (Fig. 19d). Both structural characterization and theoretical calculation results indicate that the introduction of curvature carriers induces strain on the RuN2B1 site, elongating the bond length between the single-atom Ru and the adjacent coordinating heteroatom B, while compressing the bond length between the single-atom Ru center and the adjacent coordinating heteroatom N. This results in the accumulation of positive charges near the Ru center and the disappearance of spin polarization, thereby achieving optimal H* binding strength. This study highlights the significant role of carrier curvature in modulating the electronic structure and catalytic performance of active sites. Recently, Su Yaqiong's group investigated the theoretical activity of the ORR concerning the curvature effect of FeN4-doped carbon nanotubes[57]. Utilizing density functional theory, the study thoroughly examined the ORR of FeN4 CNT catalysts with varying diameters, focusing on the adsorption of oxygen both on the exterior and interior surfaces of the carbon nanotubes. The researchers proposed that the curvature of the carbon nanotubes alters the electronic structure of the FeN4 single atoms, thereby regulating the adsorption and desorption of reactants, intermediates, and products throughout the electrocatalytic process. Additionally, the impact of outer and inner oxygen adsorption on the ORR activity was further explored. The influence of curvature on the ORR activity of FeN4-doped carbon nanotube catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 20. Taking all factors into consideration, we can conclude that subtle changes in curvature radius have a profound impact on the electronic structure of SACs, which further determines their adsorption capacity and activation efficiency towards reactants. Extensive research has confirmed that by adjusting the curvature of curved carbon materials, graphene, carbon nanotubes, and nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes, their electronic structure and catalytic activity can be significantly regulated. It is worth noting that different materials have varying sensitivities to curvature changes; Some catalysts exhibit excellent activity under high curvature conditions, while others perform even better under low curvature conditions In practical applications, by finely adjusting the curvature of carbon based supports, we can change the bond length and bond angle between metal atoms and coordinating atoms, thereby affecting the position of the d-band center. This means that when designing catalysts, key factors such as the coordination number of metal single atoms on carbon based materials, the spatial structure between atoms, and the bond length and angle of coordination bonds must be comprehensively considered. These factors collectively determine the performance of the catalyst, providing a theoretical basis and design guidance for optimizing specific catalytic reactions. Through this precise material design, we can develop more efficient and selective catalysts to meet urgent needs in fields such as energy conversion and environmental protection[58]. 2.5 Metal high-curvature SACs We understand that in the design of catalysts, the interaction between metal atoms and coordination atoms on supporting materials (such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur and phosphorus) is crucial for the stability of metal single-atoms. In addition to conventional metal non-metal chemical bonds, single-atom alloys (SAAs) have also been developed, which utilize metal- metal interactions to achieve single-atom dispersion on metal supports. In these high-curvature SACs, the usual non-metallic support is replaced by metal support, while the active metal single-atom interacts with the support through metal-metal bonds. In the entire field of catalyst research, the study of metal support interaction (MSI) is a core theme that runs through synthesis, structural analysis, and exploration of catalytic mechanisms. High-curvature metal catalysts are typically constructed of nanometer-sized particles, which may be spherical, cubic, or otherwise irregularly shaped. These nanoparticles have a high surface curvature, surface defects of different sizes, and a diverse arrangement of atoms. In contrast, non-high-curvature metal catalysts typically consist of larger particles and may be shaped with a more regular crystal structure, such as a cube or octahedron. These particles have a lower surface curvature, fewer defects, and a more regular arrangement of atoms. It is these differences that make for a high proportion of single-atom site catalysts (SAAs) and a relatively high number of active sites. These active sites are typically surface atoms, which provide more opportunities to catalyze the reaction than non-high-curvature metal catalysts. SAAs have significant advantages: first, each metal atom acts as the active center, resulting in extremely high atomic efficiency; Secondly, the special structure of SAAs can effectively adjust the adsorption characteristics of reactants, thereby optimizing the catalytic performance. Compared with the isolated metal sites on non-metallic supports, the single-atom sites in SAAs that are regulated by the electronic structure of the surrounding metals are more stable, and the interaction between adjacent active sites may be more significant due to the smaller coordination number of surface atoms. This interaction may lead to synergistic effects, making SAAs more suitable for participating in multimolecular catalytic reactions. Compared to conventional alloys, SAA is able to maximize the use of active atoms while maintaining the electronic properties similar to those of free atoms. In addition, the activation of reactant molecules and the adsorption of intermediates usually occur at different metal sites of SAAs, which helps to break the direct correlation between reaction activation energy and adsorption energy, thereby improving the efficiency of catalytic conversion. Therefore, monoatomic alloy catalysts have great development potential and broad application prospects. By continuously refining the alloy grains, the alloy grains highlight the obvious high curvature effect. For example, Sibei Zou et al. reported a new idea for the synthesis of monoatomic alloys[59], jumping out of the framework of traditional monoatomic alloy preparation, using the strategy of "island effect" to fix the relative atomic ratio of two metals in the fixed alloy (Ru/Ni = 25 at%)( Fig. 21a).They also revealed the effect of catalyst size on reaction selectivity (Fig. 21b), with up to 100 % selectivity for CO generation on smaller nanoalloy islands, and CH4 selectivity gradually increasing as the catalyst size increased. In addition, the conversion rate of CO2 was the highest on the 1.0 nm nanoalloy island, which highlighted the excellent catalytic activity of the Ru single-atom site, and the conversion rate gradually decreased with the further increase of size (Fig. 21c,d). The results of the effect of temperature on the reactivity of CO2 hydrogenation showed that the conversion of CO2 increased significantly with increasing temperature on the smaller nanoalloy islands, and 100 % CO selectivity was maintained at all tested temperatures (Fig. 21e). By comparing with other catalysts in the literature, it is proved that the activity of RuNi single-atom alloy catalyst is not only far higher than that of traditional RuNi alloy catalysts, but even higher than that of Pt-based catalysts, showing significant superiority (Fig. 21f). Finally, the long-term stability test results showed that the activity and selectivity of the catalyst remained stable over the course of the reaction for up to 140 hours on the smaller nanoalloy islands, which fully demonstrated the good stability of the RuNi single-atom alloy catalyst (Fig. 21g). According to research conducted by Georgios Kyriakou et al., individual, isolated Pd atoms on a Cu surface can significantly reduce the energy barriers for hydrogen adsorption and subsequent desorption on Cu metal surfaces[60]. Hydrogen dissociation is facile at the Pd atomic sites, and its binding on Cu is weak, resulting in high selectivity for hydrogenation reactions of styrene and acetylene compared to pure Cu or Pd metals. TPD curve of H2 desorption on 0.01 ML Pd/Cu(111) alloy. The curve shows a single desorption peak that shifts to low temperatures as the H2 adsorption capacity increases, consistent with the secondary desorption process ( Fig. 22a). However, the TPD curve for H2 desorption on the surface of 0.1 ML Pd/Cu(111) alloy showed a lower desorption peak (175 K), and the desorption increased significantly with increasing H2 exposure9 (Fig. 22b). The TPD desorbed by H2 on the last 1 ML of Pd/Cu(111) alloy showed a wider desorption peak and reached saturation after exposure to a small dose of H2, indicating the presence of multiple different adsorption sites on the surface (Fig. 22c). In general, the effect of Pd coverage on the desorption of H2 on the surface of Pd/Cu alloy was demonstrated by TPD experiments, revealing that the presence of Pd monoatomic entities can reduce the dissociation barrier and binding energy of H2, thereby promoting the desorption of H2. The higher the electron density, the stronger the adsorption capacity of Pd atoms to H2, thereby reducing the binding energy of H2. In addition, the interaction between the Pd atom and the Cu atom at the edge of the step is weak, which also helps to reduce the binding energy of H2, thereby improving the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Single-atom alloy catalysts have the potential to replace traditional precious metal catalysts in order to reduce costs and improve catalytic efficiency. Although SAAs have shown their unique advantages and potential wide applications in the catalytic conversion of CO2 and CH4, there are still challenges in constructing efficient SAAs structures, achieving effective activation of CO2 and CH4 molecules, and precise control of product selectivity. 3 Different electrocatalytic applications for high-curvature SACs 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) HER is a crucial concept in electrochemistry. It refers to the electrolysis of water, during which protons or hydrated hydrogen ions undergo a reduction reaction by receiving electrons at the cathode. This process ultimately generates hydrogen gas, which precipitates from the electrode surface. SACs demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity and stability in HER due to their optimal atomic utilization efficiency and unique electronic structure. The defining feature of SACs is the dispersion of metal atoms as individual entities on a support material, allowing each metal atom to function as an active site in the catalytic process. In the HER, the interaction between the metal and the support significantly influences catalytic performance. This interaction is largely determined by the local coordination environment of the support and the electron transfer between the single atoms and the support. The following four cases illustrate the practical application of high-curvature SACs in HER: The FT-EXAFS spectra of Pt/OLC, PtO2, Pt foil, and Pt ligand/OLC, as analyzed and compared by Jianwei Fan et al.[25], revealed that Pt/OLC exhibits a Pt-C/O bond characteristic peak similar to that of PtO2 at 1.67 Å, indicating that Pt single atoms are primarily coordinated with C and O rather than forming metal clusters. Both XANES and XPS Pt 4 f spectra confirm that Pt in Pt/OLC is in the + 2 oxidation state ( Fig. 23a, b, c). Through DFT modeling of PtO2C295, it is found that Pt is connected to C and O, and the diffusion barrier for Pt on the surface is as high as 3.2 eV, significantly higher than the 0.75 eV on the C300 surface, indicating that the Pt single-atom structure in Pt/OLC is stable and resistant to migration (Fig. 23d, e). First principles calculations indicate that the enhanced local electric field at the tip of Pt sites on curved carriers promotes the reaction kinetics of hydrogen evolution. Thanks to the high-curvature of the OLC carrier surface, Pt sites form tips and generate local electric field effects, inducing proton aggregation around Pt sites and promoting proton coupled electron transfer (PECT) processes, ultimately exhibiting excellent HER performance. This work proposes a new strategy to enhance the activity of single-atom sites by regulating the structure of nanocarbon carriers and also provides an effective characterization approach based on synchrotron radiation fine structure analysis and theoretical calculations. Tan Yongwen mentioned three key points in his research on Rational strain engineering of single-atom ruthenium on non-profit MoS2 [49].A single-atom Ru modified nanoporous MoS2 (np-MoS2) (Ru/np MoS2) catalyst with a bicontinuous structure was constructed using chemical vapour deposition spontaneous redox doping method. HER was selected as the model reaction in an alkaline system to explore the synergistic effect between Ru sites and SVs; By changing the strain of the system, the synergistic effect between sulphur vacancies and Ru sites is enhanced, thereby altering the catalytic behavior of active sites. The increase in reactant density in the strained sulphur vacancies and the acceleration of HER on Ru sites are achieved. The optimal catalyst only requires an overpotential of 30 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2, with a Tafel slope of 31 mV dec−1, surpassing state-of-the-art and commercial catalysts. In addition, it also has excellent stability.; Combining DFT calculations, operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and environmental pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-XPS) techniques, it was determined that the applied strain can effectively enhance the aggregation of OH- and H2O in sulphur vacancies, leading to an increase in the density of reactants in the inner Helmholtz plane and greatly accelerating proton transfer to the Ru site. Meanwhile, the bending strain of Ru/np MoS2 can effectively regulate the electronic structure of single-atom Ru, thereby more effectively catalyzing the dissociation of H2O and the coupling of H-H. Xiaoning Wang et al. designed a series of catalysts with lanthanide single atoms (La, Ce, Pr, Nd, and Lu) embedded in ultra-small Pt nanoclusters (NCs). The mass activity of these catalysts is 14.3 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C, and they also exhibit enhanced tolerance to CO. In the electrocatalyst, different active sites should be uniformly distributed at the atomic level and synergize with the primary active sites[61]. In electrocatalysts, different active sites should be uniformly distributed at the atomic level and synergize with the primary active sites. By adjusting the d-band center, these active sites can promote the kinetics of the interfacial HOR, enhance resistance to CO poisoning, and simultaneously improve the structural stability of the electrocatalyst [62–66]. To maximize atomic utilization, the electrocatalyst should have ultrasmall dimensions [67–70]. However, despite these clear requirements, a Pt-based electrocatalyst that simultaneously meets all these conditions has not yet been developed in this field. His key innovation lies in the fact that the single-atom of hydrophilic lanthanide elements in t nanoclusters can serve as a Lewis acid site for selective OH- adsorption, regulating the binding strength of intermediates on Pt sites and promoting HOR kinetics by accelerating the binding of OH- and *H/*CO. The isolated La atom coordinated with Pt exhibits electron deficiency and can attract OH− in an alkaline environment ( Fig. 24a). The projected density of states (PDOS) indicates that La1Pt NCs have a higher proportion of electrons near the Fermi level, leading to increased electron transfer and conductivity (Fig. 24b). The hybridization of La's d-orbitals with Pt's or O's orbitals shifts the d-band center of Pt NCs upwards, enhancing the interaction between adsorbates and metal atoms (Fig. 24c). The surface of La1Pt NCs exhibits enhanced interaction with OH−, resulting in lower OH binding energies (OHBEs). Besides OHBE, the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔGH) is also used to estimate the HOR catalytic activity (Fig. 24d). The La site shows negligible H adsorption, while the ΔGH of other active sites is close to or slightly higher than that of Pt NCs, indicating that H binding energy (HBE) is not the main factor (Fig. 24e). The Gibbs free energy diagram reveals that the Tafel step is the first step, and the H2 dissociation free energy of La1Pt NCs is higher than that of Pt NCs (Fig. 24f). In the Volmer step, La1Pt NCs exhibit a lower reaction barrier, but water formation is the rate-determining step (RDS), and the RDS reaction free energy on La1Pt NCs is lower than that on Pt NCs. Yan Liu et al. designed a B,N co-doped carbon-supported ruthenium catalyst (RuBNC2000) to achieve HER[56].As shown in Fig. 25, RuBNC2000 has lower overpotential, faster hydrogen evolution kinetics, and larger TOF values compared to RuBNC8000 under the same conditions, and overall performance is significantly better than RuBNC8000. Meanwhile, after about 6 hours of electrolysis, its electrocatalytic performance tends to stabilize, reaching a stable electrolysis time of up to 24 hours Highly curved tubular B, N co doped carbon loaded ruthenium (Ru) single-atom site (RuN2B1), with extremely low Ru loading (0.4 wt%), exhibits Pt like apparent activity and exhibits ultra-high intrinsic activity in alkaline HER environments. The main reason for choosing Ru as the active component is its lower cost and similar binding strength to Pt. Especially at an overpotential of 100 mV, the measured conversion frequency (TOF) value is as high as 10 H2 s−1, which is much higher than the curvatureless Ru based catalysts and the vast majority of reported Ru based catalysts, and is also 38 times higher than commercial Pt/C. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) OER refers to the process in which hydroxide ions or water lose electrons and generate oxygen, occurring at the cathode of an electrolytic cell. OER involves multiple electron transfer processes, and the kinetic reaction is slow, which is a key factor limiting the efficiency of the entire water electrolysis device. When high-curvature SACs are added, due to the special structure of the catalyst, the active sites of the reaction are increased, and the OER efficiency rate is accelerated. The following two examples demonstrate the practical application of high-curvature single-atoms in OER: Peng Liu and his colleagues' research demonstrates that under the condition of 1.5 V, high-curvature nanocone structures can leverage their tip effect ( Fig. 26a) to significantly enhance the local electric field [71], thereby increasing the OH- concentration on active sites by an order of magnitude and substantially boosting the activity of the OER. By precisely controlling the morphology of the electrode, they optimized the mass transfer process of reactants during the OER process on active sites, further enhancing the reaction efficiency. Given the relatively simple preparation method of nanocone array electrodes, their potential for large-scale application, along with their excellent OER performance and long-term durability under high current densities, researchers anticipate their application in practical industrial alkaline water electrolysis devices. Furthermore, they believe that this effect of kinetic optimization through local electric field enhancement may have universal applicability, aiding in the design and development of more efficient nano-electrocatalysts. On the other hand, Yong Wang and his team focused their research on the OER performance of honeycomb-like nanoporous structures[46]. They found that the H-Co(OH)2@Fe(OOH)1−xClx catalyst exhibits outstanding OER performance. During testing, this catalyst showed the smallest decrease in current, indicating its superior stability (Fig. 26b). Additionally, it had the lowest Fe leaching amount, suggesting its excellent Fe retention capability, which is one of the key reasons for its superior stability (Fig. 26d,c). Furthermore, the catalyst's potential change was minimal, allowing it to operate stably for over 130 hours, further confirming its excellent long-term stability (Figure e). Compared to most existing cobalt-based catalysts, the H-Co(OH)2@Fe(OOH)1−xClx catalyst demonstrated superior stability (Fig. 26f), further highlighting its exceptional performance in the field of OER. 3.3 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) NRR refers to the nitrogen reduction reaction, which is the process of electrochemical reduction of nitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3) under the action of a catalyst. NRR usually refers to the process in which nitrogen molecules obtain electrons on the cathode and combine with protons to generate ammonia under specific electrocatalytic conditions. The reaction mechanism of NRR can be divided into two pathways: dissociation and association. The dissociation pathway involves the cleavage of the NN triple bond, while the association pathway involves the maintenance of the bond of N2 molecules during hydrogenation. In order to improve the efficiency and selectivity of NRR, high-curvature catalysts can be added to promote nitrogen reduction. The following is an example of NRR reaction. A nanoporous MoSe2 catalyst loaded with single Au atoms/clusters, named AuSA/np MoSe2 [72], was successfully synthesized by combining the chemical vapour deposition (CVD) process and chemical etching. Among them, the high-curvature gradient of the three-dimensional np-MoSe2 nanotube structure and the strain effect caused by the formation of Au Se covalent bonds between Au and 1T-MoSe2 in Au/np-MoSe2 are crucial for achieving the anchoring of single-atom Au on np-MoSe2. In summary, a single-atom Au2 separated from np MoSe was used as a catalyst for the efficient electrochemical NRR of/np Au composite materials. The prepared AuSA/np MoSe2 catalyst achieved a high and stable NH3 yield of 30.83 % μ The ideal FE of g h− 1 mg− 1 at − 37.82 V is 0.3 %, while it is RHE2 at 0.1 m Na, which is better than most reported NRR electrocatalysts. In situ electrochemical Raman spectroscopy and DFT calculations indicate that the introduction of single-atom Au into np-MoSe2 can promote N2 adsorption and stabilize *NNH, while suppressing competitive HER content, thereby enhancing the catalytic selectivity for N reduction. This work not only paves the way for exploring and designing single-atoms anchored on two-dimensional materials but also provides new insights into regulating the reaction pathways of NRR. 3.4 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) ORR refers to the process in which oxygen obtains electrons on the electrode surface and undergoes reduction under certain electrocatalytic conditions. ORR is one of the key reactions in energy conversion equipment such as fuel cells and metal air batteries. It usually occurs at the cathode of the equipment. The following three cases demonstrate the practical application of high-curvature SACs in ORR: Guangbo Chen et al. introduced a layered porous carbon material with a highly curved surface for embedding single-metal FeN4 sites as an excellent ORR catalyst [48]. They studied the changes in current density of the catalyst at different potentials. FeN₄-hcC exhibited higher current density at high potentials, indicating its high catalytic activity ( Fig. 27a). FeN₄-hcC also had a lower overpotential and a lower H₂O₂ yield, suggesting that it more effectively utilized electrons for the target reaction (Fig. 27b). After 3000 cyclic voltammetry tests, the performance of FeN₄-C declined, while FeN₄-hcC maintained relatively stable performance, indicating the better stability of FeN₄-hcC (Fig. 27c). Additionally, Yanzhi Wang et al. investigated the immobilization of iron species within sulfur and nitrogen co-doped carbon nanospirals [10]. They evaluated the FeNS/Fe3C@CNS catalyst using cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. 27d), LSV curves under acidic conditions (Fig. 27e), and compared the Tafel slopes of the FeNS/Fe3C@CNS catalyst with different catalysts (Fig. 27f). Yan Yan et al. demonstrated its superior ORR performance[73] . Arc-Co SAC exhibited higher or lower current densities at high potentials (Fig. 27g, h), indicating its better electrocatalytic activity. Most importantly, Arc-Co SAC showed the highest current density at 0.85 V vs. RHE (Fig. 27i), suggesting its optimal performance at this potential. Sheng Zhu and his colleagues successfully designed a novel one-dimensional heterostructure ORR catalyst (FePc-{PW12}@NTs) by coupling FePc to carbon nanotubes encapsulated with polyoxometalates using a host-guest chemistry strategy [74]. The study found that the encapsulation of polyoxometalates can induce local tensile strain in single-walled NTs, thereby enhancing the interaction with FePc. Meanwhile, the strain and curvature effects of the {PW12}@NT substrate can effectively tune the geometric structure and local electronic properties of the FeN4 center to improve ORR catalytic performance. 3.5 Carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) CO2RR is an electrocatalytic process that converts carbon dioxide into other chemicals. In the process of CO2RR, the selection of catalysts is crucial for the efficiency of the reaction and the selectivity of the products. The following four cases are the practical applications of SACs in CO2RR: Tianfu Wang and his colleagues found through theoretical calculations that Ni single atoms loaded on curved carbon substrates can significantly enhance the density of states near the Fermi level and reduce the energy barrier for COOH formation, thereby enhancing electrocatalytic activity[40] . They presented the relationship between the overpotential (η) and logarithmic current density (log j mA cm⁻²) for three materials, clearly indicating that the protonation of CO2 to form the COOH intermediate is the rate-determining step ( Fig. 28a). Their high turnover frequency (TOF) values demonstrate excellent intrinsic catalytic activity (Fig. 28b); the reaction can proceed continuously at −0.7 V, and after 15 hours of continuous reaction, the Faraday efficiency (FE) for CO remains near 100 %, with only a slight decrease in current, indicating good long-term stability (Fig. 28c). Jianjun Su and his team investigated the performance of SWCNTs in CO2RR and found that the Faraday efficiency for methanol (FEMeOH) exhibits a typical volcanic dependence within the applied potential range of −0.78 to −1.03 V (Fig. 28d) [41]. At −0.9 V, the maximum current density for methanol (jMeOH) on CoPc/SWCNTs reaches 66.8 mA cm⁻², with an FEMeOH of 31.3 %, which is 7.6 times that of jMeOH in an H-type electrolytic cell (Fig. 28e); for CoPc/SWCNTs, jMeOH reaches 62.1 mA cm⁻² at −0.8 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), corresponding to an FEMeOH of 50.5 % (Fig. 28f). Du Xiwen's team's research on the clamp catalytic mechanism within metal nanopores [18]. On the surface of the bulk and nanoparticles, the adsorption between CO2 and H2O molecules and zinc atoms is very weak, with Zn-C bond lengths greater than 3 Å ( Fig. 29ab). On the concave pincer shaped sites in the pores, the bond length decreases to 2 Å, greatly enhancing the adsorption (Fig. 29c). The differential charge density shows an electron deficient state on the zinc atom, indicating that CO2 molecules on the clamp site undergo chemical adsorption and electron transfer, leading to an increase in the valence state of zinc (Fig. 29d). At the same time, the activation process of carbon dioxide on the clamp site is accelerated (Fig. 29e), and the entire reaction barrier for CO2RR is greatly reduced. This work uses laser liquid-phase ablation technology to synthesize porous Zn nanoparticles with concave surfaces for the CO2RR. The concave surface inside the porous material works like a pincer, capturing and gripping CO2 and H2O reactants, effectively reducing the energy barrier for CO2RR. In addition, the clamp mechanism is common for metal nanopores such as Co and Cu, revealing the unique catalytic mechanism of concave surfaces in metal nanopores. In summary, high curvature single atom catalysts have demonstrated outstanding performance improvements in multiple electrocatalytic reactions such as OER, HER, ORR, NRR, and CO2RR. These catalysts collectively utilize the special effects of high curvature structures, such as enhancing local electric fields through tip effects, promoting proton aggregation at active sites, and facilitating proton coupled electron transfer (PECT) processes; Strain engineering and unique geometric structures enhance the synergistic effect between sites and alter the catalytic behavior of active sites. In addition, the uniform distribution of active sites is also key to improving catalytic performance. By uniformly distributing different active sites at the atomic level and synergistically adjusting the d-band center with the main active sites, the interfacial reaction kinetics are promoted and the structural stability of the electrocatalyst is enhanced. However, although these catalysts share common strategies for improving performance, they each have their own strengths in specific approaches to catalytic mechanisms and performance optimization. For example, the Pt/OLC catalyst in HER generates a local electric field effect by forming a tip, while the H-Co(OH)2@Fe(OOH)1-xClx catalyst in OER achieves excellent stability through its honeycomb like nanoporous structure. Therefore, in different applications, we should carefully design and optimize high curvature single atom catalysts based on reaction characteristics and the intrinsic mechanism of the catalyst to achieve the best catalytic effect. 4 Challenges and future prospects 4.1 Challenges for high-curvature SACs High-curvature SACs face multiple future challenges, such as in industrial applications where they need to meet higher standards such as stability and cost-effectiveness. These factors are key indicators pursued by the industry, and for SACs to be widely applied in fields such as chemical, pharmaceutical, medical, energy, and environment, they must demonstrate excellent performance in these areas. Efficient SACs often use precious metals such as platinum as the active ingredient, which leads to increased costs. How to reduce material costs while ensuring catalytic performance is the key to achieving commercialization. Catalysts still need to continuously explore new synthesis methods, carrier materials, and catalytic system design. The development of innovative technologies may bring breakthroughs, such as using high-curvature carrier materials to improve the dispersion and utilization of single-atoms. In summary, in the future, by increasing the catalytic rate, the selectivity and stability of catalysts for specific reactions, chemical effective collisions can be increased by changing the structure of the carrier, such as turning the carrier into a nanocone [71], high-curvature porous carbon, spiral shaped nanocarbon materials, etc. The tip structure can have a local electric field, which acts on chemical reactions. The reaction substrate will exhibit a localized high concentration distribution around the tip structure of the catalyst, which is expected to accelerate the kinetic processes of chemical reactions and ultimately achieve better catalytic performance. Strengthening the theoretical research and computational simulation of high-curvature SACs can provide theoretical guidance for catalyst design and performance optimization. Future research may focus on methods such as quantum mechanics and molecular dynamics simulations to reveal the interaction mechanisms between single-atoms, ligands, and substrates in high-curvature SACs, providing more precise guidance for the regulation of catalytic reactions. 4.2 Future development of high-curvature SACs The future trends and developments of high-curvature SACs may involve the following aspects: firstly, nanostructure regulation. By adjusting the nanostructure, such as crystal plane, grain size, and lattice defects, the performance of high-curvature SACs can be further optimized. To achieve optimization of active sites and electronic structures. The second is to improve the synthesis method of catalysts and seek new synthesis strategies, such as chemical synthesis, composite material method, template method, etc., to prepare high-curvature SACs with specific structures and functions. This helps to improve the stability and performance of the catalyst, and reduce preparation costs. In this review, we can see that the size of materials varies in different dimensions, so SACs have a "carrier size" effect, that is, the smaller the carrier size, the greater the curvature of the carrier. Related research has been conducted on this. Valery Muravev's research suggests that the size of cerium dioxide (CeO2) support determines the reactivity of atomic dispersed palladium (Pd) in the oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO)[75]. Research has found that catalysts with 4 nm CeO2 exhibit exceptionally high activity in reaction atmospheres rich in CO, while catalysts with approximately 8 nm CeO2 are more suitable for dilute CO conditions. This difference is attributed to the redox properties of the palladium cerium oxide interface at different carrier sizes. In view of this, Prof. Emiel J. M. Hensen et al. used CO oxidation as a research reaction to demonstrate that the reactivity of Pd-CeO2 SAC nanoparticles with variable size carriers (4–18 nm) prepared by flame spray pyrolysis is highly dependent on the size of the CeO2 particles [76]. Although SACs can effectively utilize expensive precious metals and bring unique performance [77–79]. However, due to sintering, the dispersed catalyst becomes a compact block like object, and the stability of the catalyst is limited, which often affects its application. High-curvature SACs can also improve reaction activity by utilizing the "carrier size" effect. However, SACs have a small volume and are easily attracted when suspended in solution, leading to catalyst adhesion and a reduction in active sites, greatly reducing the catalytic ability. However, by using nano islands, SACs are fixed on a porous carrier with high surface area, avoiding the problem of single-atom aggregation. In order to improve efficiency, these expensive "precious metals" are usually used in the form of nanoparticles, which are dispersed on porous carriers with a high surface area. This ensures that many metal atoms are exposed on surfaces where gas or liquid molecules can bind and react with them. When the size of these nanoparticles is reduced to the limit of a single-atom, they exhibit new catalytic properties, which is are ideal for the target chemical reaction. The problem is that when these metals are dispersed in atomic form, they often diffuse through their carriers and aggregate to form larger particles. The aggregation of these metal atoms reduces the number of accessible active sites, thereby reducing the effectiveness of the catalyst. Under the harsh reaction conditions of existing and future applications, it is necessary to develop catalysts that avoid this aggregation process. The limitation of platinum atoms on cerium oxide small islands within porous materials to catalyze reactions without sticking to each other has always been a major stumbling block in their use. Researchers have shown that the confinement of dispersed metal atoms onto oxide nanoclusters or "nano islands" can enhance the beneficial anchoring effect( Fig. 30b), as they are dispersed and fixed on sturdy high surface area carriers [80]. The application of nanoislands provides a transformation idea for one-dimensional single-atoms to three-dimensional. Can the change in a curvature radius of one-dimensional spheres also change the performance of catalysts? How to change it? The research team led by Lin Yanwei, an assistant professor at the National University of Singapore, has developed a new method that can widely affect the reaction performance of SACs [54]. Accurate control of SAC activity has been achieved through the field effect induced by nano curvature. Researchers prepared a series of SACs with different ball diameters within a specified diameter range (50–1000 nanometers) using a high-temperature furnace method and then validated the numerical simulation results using Kelvin probe force microscopy and Raman spectroscopy. They found that higher nanocurvatures (smaller spherical diameters) generate stronger electric fields. After experimental testing of these catalysts, even if the active sites of the catalysts are exactly the same, nano curvature can still be used to control their activity. This article is thought-provoking. If a one-dimensional spherical carrier has a large radius, its curvature will be very small. If a spherical carrier with irregular and uneven surfaces is designed, the one-dimensional sphere will become three-dimensional, and the uneven areas will be similar to smaller curvature balls(Fig. 30a). Finally, expanding the application field: High-curvature SACs have broad application prospects in multiple fields such as energy conversion and storage, environmental protection, and biomedicine. Future research may combine high-curvature SACs with other advanced catalytic materials (such as two-dimensional materials, nanocrystals, etc.) to achieve more efficient, low-cost, and environmentally friendly catalytic applications. For example, energy conversion and storage; Photocatalytic WDS for hydrogen production; It can be used as a photocatalyst and exhibits high activity and stability in the process of photocatalytic WDS for hydrogen production. CO2RR: SACs can be used to reduce CO2 to syngas (CO and H2), providing new avenues for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and sustainable energy production. Fuel cell: can serve as an electrocatalyst for fuel cells, improving their performance and reducing costs. Dye wastewater treatment: can be used for photocatalytic degradation of dye wastewater, achieving efficient and low-cost wastewater treatment. Organic pollutant degradation: It can be used as an efficient photocatalyst to degrade organic pollutants such as organic pesticides and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, reducing environmental risks. Air purification: can be used as a photocatalyst to degrade harmful gases and particles in the air, improving indoor air quality. Drug synthesis: can be used as a catalyst for designing and synthesizing novel drug molecules. Biocatalysis: It can serve as an efficient enzyme replacement catalyst in biocatalytic reactions, improving reaction rate and selectivity. 5 Summary This review clearly demonstrates six key aspects of high-curvature SACs, including shape, size, convexity, dimension, curvature radius, and comparison of catalytic performance under different electrocatalytic environments (see Table 1). By reading this review, we understand that high-curvature SACs are efficient because their highly curved surfaces can promote atomic adsorption and reactions. Compared with traditional catalysts, this structure brings many advantages such as higher selectivity and yield. In addition, the review also explores various factors that affect the performance of high-curvature SACs, such as small-sized catalysts typically having higher activity, three-dimensional catalysts being more stable than one-dimensional structures, the influence of curvature radius on catalytic reactions, and the fact that different concave and convex surfaces of catalysts provide different effective contact areas. High-curvature carbon-based materials, such as small-size carbon blacks, carbon nanotubes and curly graphene, have special curvature effects, such as "tip structure", "structural distortion" and "compressive strain" effects. (1) The "tip structure" effect, that is, the local electric field effect. At the tips of high-curvature carbon, the local electric field becomes particularly strong because of the concentrated curvature. This strong electric field can make the active site of the catalyst react faster, and the catalytic reaction speed is increased. (2) The "structural distortion" effect, that is, the bond length modulation effect. The structural distortion of high-curvature carbon will cause the bond length between the metal single atoms and the carbon to change. As the bond length changes, the electronic structure of the metal atom will also change, which will affect its catalytic performance. (3) The "compressive strain" effect, that is, the d-band center effect. The compression strain applied by the high curvature material to the metal single atom will change its d-band center position. The location of the d-band center is particularly important for the adsorption and desorption processes of the catalyst. Through the compression strain, one can adjust the position of the d-band center to optimize the adsorption free energy of the catalyst to the intermediates, so that the catalytic efficiency and product selectivity can be improved. These findings stimulate further thinking: Is the performance of high-curvature SASs also related to other factors? For example, whether there is an optimal curvature value, or whether there is a specific pattern (such as a parabolic relationship) between curvature and performance. My personal opinion on high-curvature nanocarriers is that due to their strong adsorption ability, they can distribute atoms more evenly on the surface of the carrier, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. We look forward to future research verifying these patterns and bringing new insights to this field. CRediT authorship contribution statement Li Bolin: Writing – review & editing. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance of a high-curvature single-atom catalyst is highly dependent on its geometry and the type of metal atoms it carries. This review uses a combination of extensive literature research and theoretical analysis to comprehensively analyze several key aspects of high-curvature single-atom catalysts, including dimension, energy, reaction mechanism, radius of curvature, reaction selectivity, size, different metal atoms, and different types of reactions. In this paper, the unique advantages of high-curvature single-atom catalysts are successfully summarized and refined. On the one hand, it has been found that the surface of this catalyst is highly curved, which promotes the adsorption and reaction of atoms. On the other hand, this paper states that choosing the right radius of curvature is essential to optimize the catalytic process. The comprehensive literature analysis in recent years may provide important reference and enlightenment for researchers, promote the further development of the field of catalysis, and develop more advanced high-curvature single-atom catalytic materials.
